channel.title: Playing Card Probability
channel.description:
Hi, I have recently changed sets in my maths group and my homework is Probability. May i add i suck at probability soo... Heres the question
I have made the useful information [b]Bold[/b]
A playing card is drawn from the pack of [b]52 Cards[/b], It is then replaced, The pack is then shuffled and then another card is drawn. Find the probability that :-
[ul][li]The two cards were [b]both Clubs[/b][/li] [li]The two cards were [b]both Red King[/b]s[/li] [li]The first card was a [b]two[/b] and the second card was [b]red[/b][/li] [li]One card was a [b]Jack[/b] and the other card was [b]red[/b][/li] [li]One card was a [b]Club[/b] and the other was a [b]Queen[/b][/li][/ul]

item.title: Playing Card Probability
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

A given B, etc. Probability with replacement is probably the easiest it can get to.

Read full topic

item.title: Playing Card Probability
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:3, topic:340334”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=436702.msg3209018#msg3209018 date=1274052242]

  1. The two cards were both Clubs

  2. The two cards were both Red Kings

  3. The first card was a two and the second card was red

  4. One card was a Jack and the other card was red

  5. One card was a Club and the other was a Queen

A = Clubs.
P(A ∩ A) = 1/4 * 1/4 = 1/16
2.
A = Red King
P(A ∩ A) = 1/26 * 1/26 = 676
3.
A = Two
B = Red
P(A ∩ B) = 1/13 * 1/2 = 1/26

Now, do the rest yourself.
[/quote]
oh wtf. my teacher must be a dumb ass. She just told us to Wright just the fraction or percentage. e.g. 1. 2/52 or 26%[/quote]that’s to express the result, idiot (which he did)

Read full topic

item.title: Playing Card Probability
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

  1. The two cards were both Clubs

  2. The two cards were both Red Kings

  3. The first card was a two and the second card was red

  4. One card was a Jack and the other card was red

  5. One card was a Club and the other was a Queen

A = Clubs.
P(A ∩ A) = 1/4 * 1/4 = 1/16
2.
A = Red King
P(A ∩ A) = 1/26 * 1/26 = 1/676
3.
A = Two
B = Red
P(A ∩ B) = 1/13 * 1/2 = 1/26

Now, do the rest yourself.

item.title: Playing Card Probability

item.description:
@WowILikeToCode wrote:

Hi, I have recently changed sets in my maths group and my homework is Probability. May i add i suck at probability soo… Heres the question

I have made the useful information Bold

A playing card is drawn from the pack of 52 Cards, It is then replaced, The pack is then shuffled and then another card is drawn. Find the probability that :-

[ul][li]The two cards were both Clubs[/li]
[li]The two cards were both Red Kings[/li]
[li]The first card was a two and the second card was red[/li]
[li]One card was a Jack and the other card was red[/li]
[li]One card was a Club and the other was a Queen[/li][/ul]
